body.p:
To His Excellency
The Governor of Kentucky

Your Petitioner William Crowdus and others citizens of Marion County state that said William Crowdus, Henly Crowdus John Calvert, William Baxter and James Baxter were jointly indicted in the Marion Circuit Court on a charge of stabbing and wounding Harrison Thornton -- The cause was tried as to William Crowdus at Nov term 1861 -- At the calling of the cause, niether Wm nor James Baxter appeared -- the others asked and had awarded them seperate trials whereupon at the instance of the commonwealths atty William Crowdus was put on trial -- The evidence showed the conflict out of which the indictment grew to have been at Thorntons house on the Lebanon and Danville Turnpike That the five accused persons were by the house from Lebanon when finding there two others viz William Lamb and G H Glascock a quarrel arose between William Baxter and Lamb refering to some former grudge -- when Lamb retiring into the house the two Baxters who were brothers went in also, during the altercation which ensued William Crowdus went into the house and was engaged and stabbed by Lamb or Thornton or both, being badly wounded, Thornton being also wounded about the same -- Lamb and Thornton who were brothers in law
were the principal witnesses testifying as to the act of stabbing, and against William Crowdus, -- The defendent offered to introduce as witnesses Henly Crowdus and Calvert offering to prove by them facts showing he went into the house for the purpose of preventing violence and not to com^m^it it himself, and was there assaulted and stabbed by Lamb or Thornton without provocation before he used a knife in his own defence, this being overruled, Defendent moved the court to discharge John Calvert from the indictment in order to use him as a witness to prove the above facts in his behalf, there being no sufficient evidence to put Calvert on his trial (see such 2 ยง2 Crim code) and their motion was overruled because Calvert was not there also on trial and Crowdus was thus deprived of the testimony of two witnesses because of the indictment against them while Thornton and Lamb who ^or one of them^ had wounded him in the encounter were the main witnesses against him -- The affidavits of H Crowdus and Calvert are herewith submitted -- By the verdict and judgment in the case a fine of $100 was imposed on Wiliam Crowdus He is a very poor man and has a family -- Believing his case to be a proper one for executive interposition we respectfully ask a
remission of said judgments -- March 1862 --
William Crowdus says he believes the states of the foregoing petition are true and also those of Henly Crowdus & Jno Calvert on the next page --

Sworn to by Wm Crowdus before me April 19th 1862
H. H. Goode J. P. M. C

I was one of William Crowdus Counsel on his trial & made the motion to discharge Calvert and admit him as a witness according to such 2 ยง2 of the criminal code, believing as I do now that the proof wholly failed as to him, and I did not understand the court to overrule the motion because this was any case proven against him but on the grounds that he could only exercise the power conferred by said section where the witnesses was jointly with the other Deft on trial -- I was surprised at this decision and still believe it ^was^ erronious & caused the infliction of the fine on Crowdus which as his counsel I respectfully ask may be remitted --
We join in the petition of William Crowdus

H. H. Goode
. M Moore
John. A. Good
Wm Brown
E G Chandler
E. G. Martin
Wm H Fidler
J. W Mcginnis

Henly Crowdus who is mentioned in the within petition states on oath that when himself, William Crowdus, Calvert William Baxter, and James Baxter came by Thorntons house, William Lamb was standing in or near the house and a quarrel arose between him and William Baxter, and James Baxter also became involved in it and they all having gone into the ^house^ where the altercation continued William Crowdus went in and told William Baxter to come out of the house, and about that time I saw Thornton advancing upon him with a drawn knife and shortly afterwards I saw William Crowdus come out bleeding, and badly stabbed in two places, I did not see Calvert do anything at the time --
Sworn to before me by Henly Crowdus this 18th March 1862

John Calvert who is mentioned above states that the quarrel arose between the two Baxters and Lamb as stated by Henly Crowdus who all came into Thorntons house before Wm Crowdus, who when he went in told William Baxter to "come out and have no difficulty, and immediately afterwards I saw Thornton and Lamb both the latter with a knife drawn attack him & I saw Crowdus afterwards was stabbed as stated by Henly Crowdus -- I was to keep the peace myself sworn to before me by Jno Calvert April 15 1862
